subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] New Character needed?
msgSnippet: ... So if the letter Shush appears by itself, how do we distinguish it from Thither? If we had a special colon character, we could write the special colon
messageBody:
tinyallen wrote:
>
>
> I've been looking at the great tutorials available on the Web and
> the QS Manual, and I've noticed something.
> The letterforms are not ambiguous without a baseline.
> It's easy enough to read a line of text, small letters establish
> the bottom and top of the baseline and make the rest readable. But
> when writing a single character or very short string, there will
> sometimes be problems.
> One possible fix is to change the Colon character (or make a new
> one) that places dots at the baseline and the top of the small
> characters, establishing the relative 'altitude' of the letter(s) in
> question.
> Another possibility is using this in place of a Namer Dot, though
> the conflict of purposes may cause problems.
> As I understand it, the block-structure of Unicode assignments
> means that our current proposals have a few characters free anyway.
>
> How about it, Fontmakers?
>

So if the letter Shush appears by itself, how do we distinguish it from
Thither? If we had a special colon character, we could write the special
colon character before the single letter, and then write the single
letter itself. That way we could see if the letter is Shush or Thither
by where it sits in relation to the colon dots. I'm just making sure I
understand the idea right.

I like this idea, my only objection being that it may take the space for
something more needed. I would like to see a special character for the
Ado-Roar ligature, since I think this sequence needs its own
representation, so that in words like "arrest" <qs>arest</qs> doesn't
contain too many vowels at the start that make reading tricky--but that
request is another matter. So yes, it sounds like a good idea, but on
balance, is it worth the space?

Paul
